reg:regulation.reg:effective:
July 9, 1999, except sections
10, 23 and 24 effective July 1, 2000
reg:regulation.reg:title: Food Premises Regulation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this regulation:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Public Health Act;
container means a food receptacle or covering used to package, wrap, contain or cover food;
contaminate means to expose to conditions that permit

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the introduction of foreign matter including filth, a poisonous substance or a pest,
the introduction or multiplication of disease-causing micro-organisms or parasites, or
the introduction or production of toxins;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: equipment means any item that is used in the operation of food premises and includes stoves, ovens, ventilation systems, slicers, grinders, mixers, scales, cutting surfaces, tables, shelves, refrigerators, freezers, sinks, ice makers, trolleys, vending machines, dishwashing machines and lighting systems;
fish means fin fish and molluscan and crustacean shellfish;
food means any raw or processed substance intended for human consumption;
food bank means a non-profit organization that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: operates with the exclusive intent of feeding the hungry, and
receives, holds, packages, repackages or distributes food to be consumed off the premises but does not process food;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: food contact surface means the surface of equipment or utensils with which food normally comes into contact;

food premises means any place where food intended for public consumption is sold, offered for sale, supplied, handled, prepared, packaged, displayed, served, processed, stored, transported or dispensed;
food service establishment means food premises in which food is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: processed,
served or dispensed to the public, and
intended for immediate consumption,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: but does not include food premises in which

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: only prepackaged food that is not potentially hazardous food is served or dispensed to the public, or
unpackaged food that is not potentially hazardous food is served or dispensed to the public if the service or dispensing does not result in the risk of a health hazard occurring;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: handwashing station means a hand basin provided with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: hot and cold running water,
soap in a dispenser, and
a method of hand drying that uses single service products;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: operator includes a manager and an owner or lessor of the premises;
pest means any animal or arthropod destructive to the sanitary operation of food premises and includes rats, mice, cockroaches and flies;
potentially hazardous food means food in a form or state that is capable of supporting the growth of disease-causing micro-organisms or the production of toxins;
process means to make raw food ready to eat and includes washing, rinsing, cooking, smoking, salting, canning, freezing, pasteurizing and reprocessing of previously processed food;
sanitize means to treat by a process that effectively destroys micro-organisms including pathogens;
single service means designed to be used only once and then discarded;
utensil means kitchenware, tableware, glasses, cutlery or other similar items used in the preparation, service, storage or consumption of food;
voluntary caterer means a member of an organization or agency that volunteers to prepare food for functions or gatherings.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Food present in food premises is deemed to be offered for sale and for human consumption.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This regulation applies to every food premises other than

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a bed and breakfast establishment operated in a private residence,
a food bank,
premises in which food is prepared or served by voluntary caterers for functions or gatherings limited to members of their own organization and invited guests,
premises that are governed by the Milk Industry Act or the Fish Inspection Act,
an assisted living residence under the Community Care and Assisted Living Act, if the assisted living residence

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: has no more than 6 residents, as defined by that Act, and
would be a single family residence if it were not being used as an assisted living residence,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a slaughter establishment licensed under the Meat Inspection Regulation, and
premises in which only the following food is sold or offered for sale:

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prescribed health hazards and regulated activities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are prescribed as health hazards:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: conditions that may cause food to be contaminated;
potentially hazardous food.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The operation of food premises is prescribed as a regulated activity.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Plans and specifications to be approved

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not construct or make alterations to food premises unless the plans and specifications for the construction or alteration have been approved by a health officer.
An applicant for approval under subsection (1) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: submit to a health officer a copy of the complete plans and specifications for the construction or alteration, and
provide the health officer with any other information the health officer reasonably requires.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The health officer may approve, by issuing a permit to the applicant, the plans and specifications submitted under subsection (2) if the plans and specifications indicate that the proposed construction or alteration conforms to the requirements of section 4.
Every person who constructs or makes alterations to food premises must ensure that the food premises are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: of sound construction and in good repair,
designed to ensure the safe and sanitary handling of food,
constructed from materials that are

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: suitable for their intended purpose, and
durable, easily cleaned and free from any noxious or toxic substance,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: separate from and without direct access to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: any area in which activities are carried out that are incompatible with the safe handling of food,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: connected to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a source of potable water, and
a waste disposal system operating in compliance with the requirements of the government agency that has jurisdiction,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: capable of supplying hot and cold water that is adequate in quantity and pressure to meet the water needs of the food premises,
provided with artificial lighting that is adequate in intensity to permit the sanitary operation and maintenance of the premises,
equipped with ventilation equipment that is adequate to prevent the accumulation of smoke, grease, water vapour and objectionable odours, and
supplied with equipment that will ensure the safe and sanitary handling of food.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 361/99, s. 2.]

bcl:section.bcl:text: If food premises provide seating for dining purposes and are not subject to building bylaws adopted under the Local Government Act, the operator must ensure that washroom facilities are provided for the use of the dining patrons in accordance with B.C. Reg. 216/2006, the British Columbia Building Code Regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not operate food premises unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the plans and specifications for the premises have been approved under section 3, and
the premises are constructed and maintained in accordance with the permit issued under that section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 69/2012, Sch. 1, s. 5.]

bcl:section.bcl:text: Every operator of food premises must immediately notify a health officer of any circumstance that exists in the food premises that may cause a health hazard.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Permit to operate food service establishment

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not operate a food service establishment unless the person holds a permit issued under this section.
A person who wishes to operate a food service establishment must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: apply to a health officer, and
provide the health officer with any information the health officer reasonably requires.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A health officer may issue a permit to operate a food service establishment to a person who complies with the Act and this regulation.

A health officer may refuse to issue a permit under subsection (3) to any person who, in the opinion of the health officer, has demonstrated that the person is not capable of operating a food service establishment in accordance with the Act and this regulation.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 49/2009, s. 2 (a).]
A permit issued under subsection (3) is not transferable.
The holder of a permit issued under subsection (3) must post the permit in a conspicuous location in the food service establishment.

An operating permit issued under section 2.05 of B.C. Reg. 148/74, the Sanitation and Operation of Food Premises Regulations, that is valid and subsisting on the day that this regulation comes into force is deemed to have been issued under this section.

Every operator of a food service establishment must hold a certificate, issued by a health officer, for the successful completion of the food handler training program known as FOODSAFE or its equivalent.

Every operator of a food service establishment must ensure that, while the operator is absent from the food service establishment, at least one employee present in the establishment holds the certificate referred to in subsection (1).

bcl:section.bcl:text: Every operator of food premises must ensure that all food on the premises is obtained from

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: food premises for which plans and specifications have been approved under section 3,
a slaughter establishment licensed under the Meat Inspection Regulation, or

a source that is approved by the government of Canada, the Provincial government, the government of another province or territory, or an official or agency of any of those governments under whose authority food safety standards are established and enforced.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Every operator of food premises must ensure that all food on the premises is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: protected from contamination, and
offered for sale, sold, supplied, handled, prepared, packaged, displayed, served, processed, stored, transported and dispensed in a sanitary manner and without risk of spoilage.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An operator of food premises must not store, display, offer for sale or sell food that is contaminated or unfit for human consumption.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Every operator of food premises that processes food must ensure that the food is processed in a manner that makes it safe to eat.
Every operator of food premises must ensure that potentially hazardous food is stored or displayed at a temperature of not more than 4C or not less than 60C.
Every operator of food premises must ensure that frozen food is stored, displayed or transported at a temperature of not more than −18C.
Every operator of food premises must ensure that each carcass is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: stored at a temperature of 4C or less, or
kept in a processing area

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at a temperature of 10C or less, or
for a period of 2 hours or less.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless it is served in a container that prevents contamination, an operator of food premises must not serve food to a customer if that food has been previously served to another customer.
Potentially hazardous food that has been previously served to a customer must not be served to another customer even if it is served in a container that prevents contamination.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Equipment, utensils and food contact surfaces
bcl:section.bcl:text: Every operator of food premises must ensure that all equipment, utensils and food contact surfaces used on the premises are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: constructed from materials that are

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: suitable for their intended purpose, and
durable, easily cleaned and free from any noxious or toxic substance,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in good working order, and
operated in a manner that ensures the safe and sanitary handling of food.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Every operator of food premises must ensure that the premises and the equipment and utensils used on the premises are maintained in a sanitary condition.

Without limiting subsection (1), every operator of food premises must ensure that the equipment, utensils and food contact surfaces used on the premises are washed and sanitized in a manner that removes contamination.
Every operator of food premises must provide the facilities and equipment necessary to meet the requirements of subsections (1) and (2).

bcl:section.bcl:text: An operator of food premises must not permit equipment or materials that are not required for the operation of the premises to be stored on the premises.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Every operator of food premises must ensure that all refrigeration and hot holding equipment

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is of a type and capacity that is adequate to meet the needs of the premises, and
is capable of maintaining the temperatures required by section 14.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Every operator of food premises must ensure that all refrigeration and hot holding equipment is equipped with a thermometer that is accurate within 1C.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An operator of food premises must not allow utensils or containers that are designed for single service use to be used more than once.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Every operator of food premises must ensure that each employee

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: wears clean clothing and footwear,
exhibits cleanliness and good personal hygiene, and
takes adequate measures to ensure that food is not contaminated by hair.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Every operator of food premises must ensure that no employee smokes in any area where food is prepared, dispensed or stored.
Every operator of food premises must ensure that all employees wash their hands as often as necessary to prevent the contamination of food.
Every operator of food premises must supply and maintain handwashing stations adequate in number and location to ensure convenient access to all employees.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An operator of food premises must not permit any person suspected to suffer from, or be the carrier of, a disease communicable through food to come into contact with any food, equipment, utensils or food contact surfaces on the food premises.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: critical control point means a location in a food service establishment or a step in the establishment's procedures where failure to comply with the Act or this regulation may result in a health hazard;
critical limit means standards that must be met to ensure that a health hazard does not occur at a critical control point.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Every operator of a food service establishment must develop, maintain and follow written procedures to ensure that a health hazard does not occur in the operation of the establishment.
The written procedures required by subsection (2) must include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identification of all critical control points,
critical limits for those critical control points,
the procedures to be followed to ensure adherence to the critical limits, and
the actions to be taken in the event that the critical limits are not adhered to.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Every operator of food premises where carcasses are handled or where food is processed or prepared must develop, maintain and follow written procedures referred to in subsection (2) that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: comply with subsection (3), and
are approved by a health officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Every operator of a food service establishment must have written procedures to ensure the safe and sanitary operation of the establishment.
The written procedures required by subsection (1) must include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the cleaning and sanitizing requirements for the establishment and for all equipment and utensils used in the establishment,
the identification of cleaning and sanitizing agents used in the establishment, including their concentrations and their uses, and
the identification of all pesticides used in the establishment, including their uses and their storage requirements.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Every operator of food premises where carcasses are handled or where food is processed or prepared must develop, maintain and follow written procedures referred to in subsection (1) that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: comply with subsection (2), and
are approved by a health officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), an operator of food premises must not permit live animals to be on the premises.
An operator of food premises may permit the following animals on the premises:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a guide dog or a service dog, as defined in the Guide Dog and Service Dog Act, but not in any area of the premises in which food is prepared, processed or stored;
live fish in an aquarium;
any other animal that a health officer determines will not pose a risk of a health hazard occurring on the premises.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Every operator of food premises must ensure that the premises are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: free of pests,
free of conditions that lead to the harbouring or breeding of pests, and
protected against the entrance of pests.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Every operator of food premises must ensure that chemicals, cleansers and other similar agents are stored in

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a room or cabinet separate from any food, and
non-food containers that are clearly labelled to identify the contents.

reg:content.reg:provisionsnote: [Provisions relevant to the enactment of this regulation: Public Health Act, S.B.C. 2008, c. 28, ss. 111, 115 and 126.]
